questions.question: Passenger pigeons no longer exist anywhere in the world. We say that they have undergone
Natural or background species extinction rates are about
The last major mass extinction occurred 65 million years ago, at which point all of the dinosaurs were lost. What do we believe caused this mass extinction?
choices: asteroid or comet colliding with the earth

questions.question: California condors, black rhinos, and mountain gorillas all have this in common:
choices: all are hunted for their meat.
all are on the threatened or endangered list.

questions.question: When the focus for saving a species from extinction is what that species can do for humans, we say that it has ________ value.
An example of existence value might be
choices: knowing that the spotted owl is saved from extinction, even if I never see one.
knowing that the panda will be saved from extinction so that future human generations can appreciate it.

questions.question: A bioprospector might search a tropical rainforest for species
choices: that have chemicals potentially useful as medicinal drugs.
that could be used to entice tourists for ecotourism.
that are related to domesticated crops, looking for genetic diversity.

questions.question: Saving the blue whale from extinction simply because it has as much right to exist as humans or any other species is based on its ________ value.
Wanting to exterminate all great white sharks because of fear, loathing, repulsion, etc., might best be called
Which of the following is false?
choices: Extinction would occur whether humans were present or absent.
Humans have caused the extinction of many species.
Extinction is a natural process. Humans have no affect on extinction.
Extinction is a natural process, although humans may increase its rate.

questions.question: The U.S. state with the highest extinction rate is
Major causes of habitat fragmentation include
Which statement is true?
choices: With a few notorious exceptions, deliberately introduced (non-native) species are usually beneficial to new habitats.
Introduced species do not harm their new environment because there is always some native organism that will keep it in check.
Many introduced species are quite important to us, while many others cause environmental devastation.

questions.question: Giant African land snails, kudzu, and European wild boars all have this in common in the U.S.:
choices: they are native to where they now exist.
they are deliberately introduced, non-native species that are creating environmental havoc.
they are non-native organisms that have helped their new habitats.
they were accidentally introduced non-native species that are now in balance with their habitats.

questions.question: A chemical pollutant becomes incorporated into body tissues at a certain concentration. Predators eating many such organisms concentrate the chemical even more. This increasing concentration in higher tropic levels is called
Poaching of wild animals is usually for
Seed banks
choices: store agricultural seed and sell it at low prices to poor farmers of developing nations.
store seed from rare and endangered species. These seeds are sold to plant collectors, with revenues used to help maintain rare and endangered species.
are long-term seed storage facilities with the purpose of preserving plant biodiversity.

questions.question: "When substantial preliminary evidence indicates that an activity can harm human health or the environment, we should take precautionary measures to prevent or reduce such harm, even if some of the cause-and-effect relationships have not been fully established, scientifically." This is
choices: called the Precautionary Principle. Although not required, it should be used to guide ecosystem research.
policy agreed upon by convention of international scientists.
a poorly thought-out ideology of extremist environmental scientists.
legislation required of all research conducted in the U.S.
